[{'created': '2020-09-16 07:23:53.000000000', 'message': "[Glusterfs] Fix delete share, Couldn't find the 'gluster_used_vols'

When we have multiple share driver backends, create a shared instance,
and the list of'self.gluster_used_vols' will only be updated on the
current node. If the RPC request to delete the share instance is sent
to other nodes,'self.gluster_used_vols' will be Cannot find the
information of the glusterfs volume we want to delete, so we need to
update'self.gluster_used_vols' when deleting the instance

Change-Id: I14835f6c54376737b41cbf78c94908ea1befde15
Closes-Bug: #1894362
(cherry picked from commit 41b0b95ef67e6c65df3125f94d2fe56b5a3630c6)
"}]
commit_message:
[Glusterfs] Fix delete share, Couldn't find the 'gluster_used_vols'

When we have multiple share driver backends, create a shared instance,
and the list of'self.gluster_used_vols' will only be updated on the
current node. If the RPC request to delete the share instance is sent
to other nodes,'self.gluster_used_vols' will be Cannot find the
information of the glusterfs volume we want to delete, so we need to
update'self.gluster_used_vols' when deleting the instance

Change-Id: I14835f6c54376737b41cbf78c94908ea1befde15
Closes-Bug: #1894362
(cherry picked from commit 41b0b95ef67e6c65df3125f94d2fe56b5a3630c6)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-02 14:15:19.000000000', 'message': 'Functional test enhancement for lock busting

This enhances our test for the import lock-busting case to include
freeing the stuck import task and letting the new and old ones proceed
to make sure that the end state looks like what we expect.

Note that this includes another task lock check after exiting the
ImportAction context before we call image save. While writing these
tests I determined that we can end up with the original task racing
to update the image locations. If set_data() took a very long time,
caused our lock to be stolen and another task is running, when our
set_data() finally finishes we may overwrite their newly-added
location when we go to save our (now stale) list. Thus, the extra
task check (imperfectly) tries to avoid us doing anything else after
our task lock is stolen.

Change-Id: I74baf53fac1c3e23f6dc743058165ecb39074626
(cherry picked from commit a86062c4924a19e9ab9d5a3412353bc0aeceaeab)
'}, {'created': '2020-09-03 15:02:03.000000000', 'message': 'Functional test enhancement for lock busting

Change-Id: I74baf53fac1c3e23f6dc743058165ecb39074626
(cherry picked from commit a86062c4924a19e9ab9d5a3412353bc0aeceaeab)
'}]
commit_message:
Functional test enhancement for lock busting

This enhances our test for the import lock-busting case to include
freeing the stuck import task and letting the new and old ones proceed
to make sure that the end state looks like what we expect.

Note that this includes another task lock check after exiting the
ImportAction context before we call image save. While writing these
tests I determined that we can end up with the original task racing
to update the image locations. If set_data() took a very long time,
caused our lock to be stolen and another task is running, when our
set_data() finally finishes we may overwrite their newly-added
location when we go to save our (now stale) list. Thus, the extra
task check (imperfectly) tries to avoid us doing anything else after
our task lock is stolen.

Change-Id: I74baf53fac1c3e23f6dc743058165ecb39074626
(cherry picked from commit a86062c4924a19e9ab9d5a3412353bc0aeceaeab)

commit_message:
Handle atomic image properties separately

The image_update() code will clobber, revert, or update lock values
in keys that we use as atomic properties. This adds an exclusion
list of properties that we handle specially and plumbs them down
to image_update() so that they will be excluded from the
add/update/delete logic.

Change-Id: Ib910274472346ce0c336cd1ead8370d5799d0b96
(cherry picked from commit 26f0311b29b18589ad134a34d5abd8ff2f82cf47)

commit_message:
Move SynchronousAPIBase to a generalized location

The base class for the tests added in test_images_import_locking provides
a mechanism to make API cals directly against the WSGI stack, without
starting a separate server and using the local networking. This is useful
for cases where fault injection of global state needs to be altered, where
this is very difficult in the existing fork-and-exec functional test
model.

This moves that test base class out to the functional module, expands the
documentation a little, and also generalizes the request methods for
wider applicability.

Change-Id: I59e3b5d5d4b69f076092b9950c0d34467a6636ad
(cherry picked from commit 36cbc50e7d70699d6ca5dd4fa81844567e39ddf0)

commit_message:
Allow authenticated token requirement for tasks

Tasks when defined can now set if they require the user submitting
a token to be authenticated.

keystone_user is now passed to actions when a token
is submitted. This requires all actions to update their submit
function, but a suitable fallthrough will exist for a cycle to
allow time.

Also fixes a minor issue around where error handling for
renamed or deprecated tasks is handled that cropped up
while testing this patch.

Change-Id: I4b51201872cb5a14f299f90e22a8b010d11a71cb

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-24 04:08:24.000000000', 'message': "libvirt:driver:Disallow AIO=native when 'O_DIRECT' is not available

Because of the libvirt issue[1], there is a bug[2] that if we set cache mode
whose write semantic is not O_DIRECT (.i.e unsafe, writeback or writethrough),
there will be a problem with the volume drivers
(.i.e nova.virt.libvirt.volume.LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver,
nova.virt.libvirt.volume.LibvirtNFSVolumeDriver and so on), which designate
native io explicitly.

That problem will generate a libvirt xml for the instance,
whose content contains

```
...
<disk ... >
  <driver ... cache='unsafe/writeback/writethrough' io='native' />
</disk>
...
```
In turn, it will fail to start the instance or attach the disk.

> When qemu is configured with a block device that has aio=native set, but
> the cache mode doesn't use O_DIRECT (i.e. isn't cache=none/directsync or any
> unnamed mode with explicit cache.direct=on), then the raw-posix block driver
> for local files and block devices will silently fall back to aio=threads.
> The blockdev-add interface rejects such combinations, but qemu can't
> change the existing legacy interfaces that libvirt uses today.

[1]: https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/058384003db776c580d0e5a3016a6384e8eb7b92
[2]: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1086704

commit_message:
libvirt:driver:Disallow AIO=native when 'O_DIRECT' is not available

Because of the libvirt issue[1], there is a bug[2] that if we set cache mode
whose write semantic is not O_DIRECT (.i.e unsafe, writeback or writethrough),
there will be a problem with the volume drivers
(.i.e nova.virt.libvirt.volume.LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver,
nova.virt.libvirt.volume.LibvirtNFSVolumeDriver and so on), which designate
native io explicitly.

That problem will generate a libvirt xml for the instance,
whose content contains

```
...
<disk ... >
  <driver ... cache='unsafe/writeback/writethrough' io='native' />
</disk>
...
```
In turn, it will fail to start the instance or attach the disk.

> When qemu is configured with a block device that has aio=native set, but
> the cache mode doesn't use O_DIRECT (i.e. isn't cache=none/directsync or any
> unnamed mode with explicit cache.direct=on), then the raw-posix block driver
> for local files and block devices will silently fall back to aio=threads.
> The blockdev-add interface rejects such combinations, but qemu can't
> change the existing legacy interfaces that libvirt uses today.

[1]: https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/058384003db776c580d0e5a3016a6384e8eb7b92
[2]: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1086704

Closes-Bug: #1841363
Change-Id: If9acc054100a6733f3659a15dd9fc2d462e84d64
(cherry picked from commit af2405e1181d70cdf60bcd0e40b3e80f2db2e3a6)
(cherry picked from commit 0bd58921a1fcaffcc4fac25f63434c9cab93b061)

commit_message:
Reduce available servers on inap-mtl01

We will be performing hardware maintenance.
This require us to shutdown some of the compute nodes,
therefore reducing effective compute capacity.

Change-Id: I017511874c98fa7ab27f811674cf67b8cdbd118d

commit_message:
Add a standalone role for creating the zuul-hosts file

This functionality is required for both the multinode
and libvirt_nodepool reproducers. This patch pulls the zuul-hosts
create into a standlone role to be called
from either the libvirt_nodepool or multinode setup
workflows.

Change-Id: Icaf94fa0e4339afe73bb4917493d012df0339d09

commit_message:
Use the admin endpoint for OpenStack API calls

All API calls should be using the admin interface. This change updates
calls for which an explicit specification of the interface was missing.

Change-Id: Idd97bd7b6145c71cc46f5792bbab44889c514483
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@suse.com>

commit_message:
Extend apparmor profile check to openSUSE Leap

The lxc version in openSUSE Leap is recent enough that the apparmor
test needs to be extended to also include this distro.

Change-Id: I5b567b486bb74ad6dd0f36c70d5ed056b45533eb
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@suse.com>

commit_message:
Add vendor override for openSUSE repositories

Zypper uses the concept of "vendor stickiness" and will refuse to
upgrade packages that require a vendor change. This change introduces
a new override variable to instruct zypper to view a list of vendors
as equivalent.

Change-Id: Ib3412b02f1edf9aae03cd5478ac2310cce3f2e8a
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@suse.com>
(cherry picked from commit f140a2e565dd85e9439f710de7ede89bc3e8afdd)

subject: Add repositories _before_ installing additional packages
messages:
[{'account_id': 19298, 'date': '2019-02-27 17:37:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19298, 'date': '2019-02-27 19:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-02-28 10:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19298, 'date': '2019-02-28 21:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Jesse for your comments. The reason I changed the other OSes is because of a comment jrosser made on IRC. He was concerned that the task ordering would be different between OSes with my change.

Would you be ok with me removing the changes for the other OSes?'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-03-01 07:46:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Thanks Jesse for your comments. The reason I changed the other OSes
 > is because of a comment jrosser made on IRC. He was concerned that
 > the task ordering would be different between OSes with my change.
 > 
 > Would you be ok with me removing the changes for the other OSes?

Perhaps i wasn't specific enough - I understood the ordering to be as it was for the same reasons as odyssey4me, it is required to be that way for centos/ubuntu and making the order functionally different for suse just does not feel right. We need new functionality instead to allow <packages> <repos> <more-packages>"}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-03-01 07:48:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > Thanks Jesse for your comments. The reason I changed the other
 > OSes
 > > is because of a comment jrosser made on IRC. He was concerned
 > that
 > > the task ordering would be different between OSes with my change.
 > >
 > > Would you be ok with me removing the changes for the other OSes?
 > 
 > Perhaps i wasn't specific enough - I understood the ordering to be
 > as it was for the same reasons as odyssey4me, it is required to be
 > that way for centos/ubuntu and making the order functionally
 > different for suse just does not feel right. We need new
 > functionality instead to allow <packages> <repos> <more-packages>

I got part way through doing this work before here https://review.openstack.org/#/c/594160/ which should really adjusted to meet this requirement, and the tests fixed up."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-03-02 12:52:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't personally have any sort of issue with the ordering being different, but the intent here is important and jrosser has suggested a way forward that's probably better - we need to implement the ability for a user to add whatever packages they like, and that would be installed after the repo changes."}, {'account_id': 19298, 'date': '2020-09-17 22:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add repositories _before_ installing additional packages

If the user wants to add additional packages to the hosts and that
package comes from an additional repository, the additional
repositories need to be added _before_ the packages are installed.

Change-Id: I9657b3de7d0147eeb7c3145643f325da83d9e139
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@suse.com>

Add `debootstrap` package

Disk image builder requires debootstrap. This change installs the
corresponding package before the amphora image is built.

commit_message:
Generalize package setup across distros

This change changes the `apt` module to the generic distro-agnostic
`package` module. It also introduces some whitespace to make the
formatting more consistent with other playbooks.

Change-Id: I40151b4fecc5c527befa328c2c77eab85c7ec723

commit_message:
Internal IPv6 addresses need to be wrapped in `[]`

This change wraps the addresses internal_lb_vip_address and
external_lb_vip_address with a pair of `[]` by using the convenient
Ansible function ipwrap.

Closes-Bug: #1775621
Change-Id: I67337b5932972b59e6c879e28e75c3567ff61eb8

Jesse, yes, there was a reason :) Jean-Phillipe had remarked that we should start doing this kind of refactoring starting in Queens. But I can also forward port it into master and then revisit Queens. What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 19298, 'date': '2020-09-17 22:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add `cpu_model` configuration option

In certain situations it can be helpful to specify the `cpu_model` for
libvirt in nova.conf. This change makes this setting configurable.

Change-Id: Iededf4d4382f67d6d18faa3aae496ac9d519d59a

commit_message:
Remove chrony if inside a container

When running ceph-mon in containers, best practice is
to have chrony/ntp configured and installed on the bare
metal and then have the container trust the system
clock, as the container should not manage the system
clock.

The chrony package get installed automatically as
part of the dependencies of other packages, which
gets removed in this change.

Also contains related changes for charms.ceph.

Change-Id: If8beb28ea5b5e6317180e52c3e32463e472276f4
Closes-Bug: #1852441
Depends-On: Ie3c9c5899c1d46edd21c32868938d3290db321e7

mapping between neutron and networking-ovn.

commit_message:
[OVN] Updates to tools/migrate_names.txt

Updates to tools/migrate_names.txt to correctly represent
mapping between neutron and networking-ovn.

networking_ovn/cmd/neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.py  neutron/cmd/ovn/neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.py
networking_ovn/tests/unit/cmd/test_neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.py  neutron/tests/unit/cmd/ovn/test_neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.py
networking_ovn/tests/unit/l3/test_l3_ovn.py  neutron/tests/unit/services/ovn_l3/test_plugin.py
networking_ovn/tests/unit/l3/test_l3_ovn_scheduler.py  neutron/tests/unit/scheduler/test_l3_ovn_scheduler.py

Change-Id: I66851f9bc4177a1d667303bc1ec1c6e7ba7a7e47

Hi Lucio-san, thanks for your comment. I tried running Manage/Unmanage Volume test, however the test was unsuccessful.
Manage/Unmanage tempest code is https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/api/volume/admin/test_volume_manage.py . The test will only work when the driver accepts volume['id'].
On the other hand, this driver does not accept the existing_ref format like {'source-name': volume['id']} or {'source-id': volume['id']}. Our storage uses the integer number to identify the volume rather than using UUID. So this driver supports the existing_ref format like {'source-id': <the integer number for the volume>}.
I believe the existing_ref of manage volume accept driver-specific values as written in https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/stein/contributor/api/cinder.interface.volume_manageable_driver.html . But in the case of driver-specific values like our storage, tempest test case does not work successfully.
If you have any idea to solve this problem, please let me know."}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2020-06-18 21:30:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I'm not sure if I understood correctly... I wonder if at some point you'd need to convert back to str those refs you converted using _str2int.

If you already have the failure logs, you may want to share with us using pastebin [0]. It might get easier to understand the issue than just looking at the code.

[0] http://paste.openstack.org/"}, {'account_id': 16373, 'date': '2020-06-19 09:20:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Only a +1 because the CI is down.  But I think you've made all the requested changes on this patch and it is good to go once the third party CI is passing.

In addition to the followup items I mentioned earlier on PS13, while you've been working on this https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656888/ merged, which moves the get_volume_stats implementation to the base volume driver.  It would be good to do a follow up patch where you make the corresponding adjustments to the HBS drivers."}, {'account_id': 31980, 'date': '2020-07-15 12:57:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Hi Rosmaita, Thanks for your comments. I solved Hitachi CI problem and Hitachi CI have been passing. I will work on items you mentioned after driver is merged.'}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2020-07-15 13:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-15 13:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

CI looks good. OpenStack logs and local.conf are present, and it looks like it is running expected amount of tests.

Still need driver docs and updates to the support-matrix.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-07-15 13:48:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+1

@Sean: we currently have the driver docs, support matrix upgrade, etc. described as post-merge activities in https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder/how-to-contribute-a-driver#After_Your_Driver_Is_Added -- so I'm in favor of going ahead and merging this, and then doing (1) the docs etc and (2) handling the get_volume_stats refactoring as followup changes."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-15 13:53:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> @Sean: we currently have the driver docs, support matrix upgrade,
 > etc. described as post-merge activities in https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder/how-to-contribute-a-driver#After_Your_Driver_Is_Added
 > -- so I'm in favor of going ahead and merging this, and then doing
 > (1) the docs etc and (2) handling the get_volume_stats refactoring
 > as followup changes.

OK, fair enough. I really would like to see that at least started, but as long as we are comfortable that it will happen soon, then that's fine."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-15 16:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-13 04:40:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add Hitachi Block Storage Driver

This driver supports Hitachi VSP storages.
Hitachi driver was deleted once in Queens release because we could not maintain
3rd party CI.
We restarted the cinder project and renewed a storage API. We upload Hitachi
driver based on REST API for Victoria release.

* Supported Protocol
 - FC
 - iSCSI

* Supported Feature
 - Volume Create/Delete
 - Volume Attach/Detach
 - Snapshot Create/Delete
 - Create Volume from Snapshot
 - Get Volume Stats
 - Copy Image to Volume,
 - Copy Volume to Image
 - Clone Volume
 - Extend Volume
 - Manage Volume
 - Unmanage Volume

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint hitachi-storage-driver

Change-Id: I926407669a75a8c52a46e07c006aa699bae46006

commit_message:
Add Hitachi Block Storage Driver

This driver supports Hitachi VSP storages.
Hitachi driver was deleted once in Queens release because
we could not maintain 3rd party CI.
We restarted the cinder project and renewed a storage API.
We upload Hitachi driver based on REST API for Victoria release.

* Supported Protocol
 - FC
 - iSCSI

* Supported Feature
 - Volume Create/Delete
 - Volume Attach/Detach
 - Snapshot Create/Delete
 - Create Volume from Snapshot
 - Get Volume Stats
 - Copy Image to Volume
 - Copy Volume to Image
 - Clone Volume
 - Extend Volume
 - Manage Volume
 - Unmanage Volume

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint hitachi-storage-driver

Change-Id: I926407669a75a8c52a46e07c006aa699bae46006

commit_message:
Cleanup test-bifrost.yaml

Remove variables that can be calculated, move global variables like
testing to the top level. Remove collecting information that should
rather be collected by CI jobs themselves.

Change-Id: Ib73a09529c8ad1640db4542d68ea3f76d6c7ea24

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-11 16:32:08.000000000', 'message': 'Move confirm resize under semaphore

The 'ResourceTracker.update_available_resource' periodic task builds
usage information for the current host by inspecting instances and
in-progress migrations, combining the two. Specifically, it finds all
instances that are not in the 'DELETED' or 'SHELVED_OFFLOADED' state,
calculates the usage from these, then finds all in-progress migrations
for the host that don't have an associated instance (to prevent double
accounting) and includes the usage for these.

In addition to the periodic task, the 'ResourceTracker' class has a
number of helper functions to make or drop claims for the inventory
generated by the 'update_available_resource' periodic task as part of
the various instance operations. These helpers naturally assume that
when making a claim for a particular instance or migration, there
shouldn't already be resources allocated for same. Conversely, when
dropping claims, the resources should currently be allocated. However,
the check for *active* instances and *in-progress* migrations in the
periodic task means we have to be careful in how we make changes to a
given instance or migration record. Running the periodic task between
such an operation and an attempt to make or drop a claim can result in
TOCTOU-like races.

This generally isn't an issue: we use the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE'
semaphore to prevent the periodic task running while we're claiming
resources in helpers like 'ResourceTracker.instance_claim' and we make
our changes to the instances and migrations within this context. There
is one exception though: the 'drop_move_claim' helper. This function is
used when dropping a claim for either a cold migration, a resize or a
live migration, and will drop usage from either the source host (based
on the "old" flavor) for a resize confirm or the destination host (based
on the "new" flavor) for a resize revert or live migration rollback.
Unfortunately, while the function itself is wrapped in the semaphore, no
changes to the state or the instance or migration in question are
protected by it.

Consider the confirm resize case, which we're addressing here. If we
mark the migration as 'confirmed' before running 'drop_move_claim', then
the periodic task running between these steps will not account for the
usage on the source since the migration is allegedly 'confirmed'. The
call to 'drop_move_claim' will then result in the tracker dropping usage
that we're no longer accounting for. This "set migration status before
dropping usage" is the current behaviour for both same-cell and
cross-cell resize, via the 'ComputeManager.confirm_resize' and
'ComputeManager.confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source' functions,
respectively. We could reverse those calls and run 'drop_move_claim'
before marking the migration as 'confirmed', but while our usage will be
momentarily correct, the periodic task running between these steps will
re-add the usage we just dropped since the migration isn't yet
'confirmed'. The correct solution is to close this gap between setting
the migration status and dropping the move claim to zero. We do this by
putting both operations behind the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE', just
like the claim operations.

Change-Id: I26b050c402f5721fc490126e9becb643af9279b4
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1879878
(cherry picked from commit a57800d3825ef2fb833d8024c6f7e5c550f55e2f)
'}]
commit_message:
Move confirm resize under semaphore

The 'ResourceTracker.update_available_resource' periodic task builds
usage information for the current host by inspecting instances and
in-progress migrations, combining the two. Specifically, it finds all
instances that are not in the 'DELETED' or 'SHELVED_OFFLOADED' state,
calculates the usage from these, then finds all in-progress migrations
for the host that don't have an associated instance (to prevent double
accounting) and includes the usage for these.

In addition to the periodic task, the 'ResourceTracker' class has a
number of helper functions to make or drop claims for the inventory
generated by the 'update_available_resource' periodic task as part of
the various instance operations. These helpers naturally assume that
when making a claim for a particular instance or migration, there
shouldn't already be resources allocated for same. Conversely, when
dropping claims, the resources should currently be allocated. However,
the check for *active* instances and *in-progress* migrations in the
periodic task means we have to be careful in how we make changes to a
given instance or migration record. Running the periodic task between
such an operation and an attempt to make or drop a claim can result in
TOCTOU-like races.

This generally isn't an issue: we use the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE'
semaphore to prevent the periodic task running while we're claiming
resources in helpers like 'ResourceTracker.instance_claim' and we make
our changes to the instances and migrations within this context. There
is one exception though: the 'drop_move_claim' helper. This function is
used when dropping a claim for either a cold migration, a resize or a
live migration, and will drop usage from either the source host (based
on the "old" flavor) for a resize confirm or the destination host (based
on the "new" flavor) for a resize revert or live migration rollback.
Unfortunately, while the function itself is wrapped in the semaphore, no
changes to the state or the instance or migration in question are
protected by it.

Consider the confirm resize case, which we're addressing here. If we
mark the migration as 'confirmed' before running 'drop_move_claim', then
the periodic task running between these steps will not account for the
usage on the source since the migration is allegedly 'confirmed'. The
call to 'drop_move_claim' will then result in the tracker dropping usage
that we're no longer accounting for. This "set migration status before
dropping usage" is the current behaviour for both same-cell and
cross-cell resize, via the 'ComputeManager.confirm_resize' and
'ComputeManager.confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source' functions,
respectively. We could reverse those calls and run 'drop_move_claim'
before marking the migration as 'confirmed', but while our usage will be
momentarily correct, the periodic task running between these steps will
re-add the usage we just dropped since the migration isn't yet
'confirmed'. The correct solution is to close this gap between setting
the migration status and dropping the move claim to zero. We do this by
putting both operations behind the 'COMPUTE_RESOURCE_SEMAPHORE', just
like the claim operations.

Change-Id: I26b050c402f5721fc490126e9becb643af9279b4
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1879878
(cherry picked from commit a57800d3825ef2fb833d8024c6f7e5c550f55e2f)

commit_message:
Add python-dracclient to be owned by Hardware Vendor SIG

This adds the first repo to be owned by the new Hardware Vendor SIG
and cleans up some misleading information in the legacy list. This repo
was never retired, just removed from ironic team governance.

Change-Id: Ie8bf14dd52b175790e6f33cee1f91ae354bbf36a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Remove support for deprecated Yum variables

The variables in yum.yml and yum-cron.yml were deprecated in Ussuri.
This patch removes them, and updates the defaults in dnf.yml.

Story: 2008160
Task: 40906

Change-Id: I97cc98dd2ff726e5885fefcab17f17796d9fd453

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-05 10:59:54.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup containers in the same loop as they are created

Split delete_missing_and_updated() into 2 methods:

  * delete_missing(), that will remove all containers installed on the
    host but missing from the given config. This runs outside of the
    loop, once.
  * delete_updated(), that will remove a container installed on the host
    (if present), that is part of the config, if config_data changed or
    didn't exist. It runs within the create loop, so the downtime
    between a container removal and creation should be shorter than
    before.
  * make delete_missing(), delete_updated() and rename_containers()
    returning True, if any container has been touched by either. Use
    that flag in order to keep the container_names contents always
    actual.
  * in order to make that cached container_names working and saving off
    extra podman ps/inspect calls, rework it to return a list instead
    of an iterator. There is no huge lists of containers, iterators buy
    us nothing here, while podman CLI calls are the more expensive
    thing and we optimize the latter instead.

(cherry picked from commit eb3d3b75bb8bf300fb52390610a6a53ddbfaa48e)
Co-Authored-By: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3c6d0670e11d035287d12f4207489a13e0891943
Closes-Bug: #1862954
"}, {'created': '2020-03-05 11:05:14.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup containers in the same loop as they are created

commit_message:
Cleanup containers in the same loop as they are created

Split delete_missing_and_updated() into 2 methods:

  * delete_missing(), that will remove all containers installed on the
    host but missing from the given config. This runs outside of the
    loop, once.
  * delete_updated(), that will remove a container installed on the host
    (if present), that is part of the config, if config_data changed or
    didn't exist. It runs within the create loop, so the downtime
    between a container removal and creation should be shorter than
    before.
  * make delete_missing(), delete_updated() and rename_containers()
    returning True, if any container has been touched by either. Use
    that flag in order to keep the container_names contents always
    actual.
  * in order to make that cached container_names working and saving off
    extra podman ps/inspect calls, rework it to return a list instead
    of an iterator. There is no huge lists of containers, iterators buy
    us nothing here, while podman CLI calls are the more expensive
    thing and we optimize the latter instead.

(cherry picked from commit eb3d3b75bb8bf300fb52390610a6a53ddbfaa48e)
Co-Authored-By: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3c6d0670e11d035287d12f4207489a13e0891943
Closes-Bug: #1862954

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-15 18:31:30.000000000', 'message': "compute: Skip cinder_encryption_key_id check when booting from volume

Idf84ccff254d26fa13473fe9741ddac21cbcf321 added this check in order for
Nova to avoid booting encrypted images created by Cinder as there is
currently no support for using such images (rotating keys etc).

The check however missed the slightly convoluted use case where this
image property is found against a volume after the volume in question is
created using an encrypted image created by cinder from an encrypted
volume. In other words:

- Cinder creates an encrypted volume A
- Cinder creates an encrypted image A from volume A
- Cinder creates an encrypted volume B from image A
- Nova attempts to boot an instance using volume B

As such this change simply ensures that the instance isn't booting from
a volume when preforming the check as it is only valid when booting from
an image.

Closes-Bug: #1895696
Change-Id: Ic92cab7362fa25050e5bbef5c3e360108365b5c7

volume. In other words:

- Cinder creates an encrypted volume A
- Glance creates an encrypted image A from volume A
- Cinder creates an encrypted volume B from image A
- Nova attempts to boot an instance using volume B

Note that Nova may request the creation of volume B or a user could also

an image.

commit_message:
compute: Skip cinder_encryption_key_id check when booting from volume

Idf84ccff254d26fa13473fe9741ddac21cbcf321 added this check in order for
Nova to avoid booting encrypted images created by Cinder as there is
currently no support for using such images (rotating keys etc).

The check however missed the slightly convoluted use case where this
image property is found against a volume after the volume in question is
created using an encrypted image created by cinder from an encrypted
volume. In other words:

- Cinder creates an encrypted volume A
- Glance creates an encrypted image A from volume A
- Cinder creates an encrypted volume B from image A
- Nova attempts to boot an instance using volume B

Note that Nova may request the creation of volume B or a user could also
do this directly through Cinder.

As such this change simply ensures that the instance isn't booting from
a volume when preforming the check as it is only valid when booting from
an image.

Closes-Bug: #1895696
Change-Id: Ic92cab7362fa25050e5bbef5c3e360108365b5c7

commit_message:
ovn: Document gap about IPv6 PD in OVN

ML2/OVN currently doesn't support IPv6 prefix delegation. This patch
adds it to the list of gaps.

Change-Id: Icf23cb9113d48322a4ba0db13a55c370e2bb14a4
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[goal] Fixing lower constraints for Ubuntu Focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal,
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Bump lower constraints to make testing work for Focal.

Co-Author: tushargite96 <tushargite96@gmail.com>
Story: #2007865
Task: #40179

Change-Id: I5f37fb5611362e550610e2094d9cb3778548bf47

> Could you share any details why please? Maybe this should be
 > addressed elsewhere

Andrii, This was the error that I got.

ubuntu@ubuntu:~/openstack-helm$ kubectl logs placement-api-6b8d86c8f7-p5mz8 -n openstack
+ COMMAND=start
+ start
++ type -p placement-api
+ cp -a /var/lib/openstack/bin/placement-api /var/www/cgi-bin/placement/
+ '[' -f /etc/apache2/envvars ']'
+ source /etc/apache2/envvars
++ unset HOME
++ '[' '' '!=' '' ']'
++ SUFFIX=
++ export APACHE_RUN_USER=www-data
++ APACHE_RUN_USER=www-data
++ export APACHE_RUN_GROUP=www-data
++ APACHE_RUN_GROUP=www-data
++ export APACHE_PID_FILE=/var/run/apache2/apache2.pid
++ APACHE_PID_FILE=/var/run/apache2/apache2.pid
++ export APACHE_RUN_DIR=/var/run/apache2
++ APACHE_RUN_DIR=/var/run/apache2
++ export APACHE_LOCK_DIR=/var/lock/apache2
++ APACHE_LOCK_DIR=/var/lock/apache2
++ export APACHE_LOG_DIR=/var/log/apache2
++ APACHE_LOG_DIR=/var/log/apache2
++ export LANG=C
++ LANG=C
++ export LANG
+ mkdir -p /var/run/apache2
mkdir: cannot create directory '/var/run/apache2': Permission denied
ubuntu@ubuntu:~/openstack-helm$"}, {'account_id': 29144, 'date': '2020-09-16 16:20:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2020-09-16 18:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8863, 'date': '2020-09-16 18:13:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I'm seeing the same logic for other components using apache, though they still use 42424 user. Lets hold on with it for now"}, {'account_id': 31707, 'date': '2020-09-16 19:00:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18511, 'date': '2020-09-16 19:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2020-09-17 00:49:20.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+2 by Chris Wedgwood <cw@f00f.org>

unlike nova api that is run on apache only with tls, placement-api is always run on apache. commit_message:
Add integration tests with port forwarding

Floating IP port forwarding by ml2/ovn uses OVN load balancers.
Integration tests with ovn_octavia_provider here are done to
ensure that these two functionalities can coexist.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741303/
Change-Id: I4b5ded003cbb3c9c4c0bc026f0e9b396f2665531

openstackinfra is a founder on the channel which is what we want. We should also add this channel to the accessbot config to ensure the other chanops management can be done.

https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/src/branch/master/accessbot/channels.yaml#L106-L107 is where the old channels config is for that (don't remove the old channel, add the new one).

You can do that in this change too."}, {'account_id': 22477, 'date': '2020-09-17 18:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22477, 'date': '2020-09-17 18:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Switch airship's gerritbot channel

This switches the Airship project's gerritbot config to use the
new #airshipit-gerritbot channel, instead of the #airshipit channel.
This will help make sure conversation doesn't get missed in #airshipit.

commit_message:
api: Set min, maxItems for server_group.policies field

As noted inline, the 'policies' field may be a list but it expects one
of two items.

Change-Id: I34c68df1e6330dab1524aa0abec733610211a407
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1894966

Already done the draft code here, currently i am doing the changes in this patch to address Saravanan comments, enhancement changes and test cases. will try to close this patch as soon as possible.'}, {'account_id': 22865, 'date': '2020-08-31 11:39:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22865, 'date': '2020-09-03 09:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 22865, 'date': '2020-09-03 09:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2020-09-03 10:37:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-09-08 15:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

To make tripleo-ansible-centos-8-molecule-tripleo_derived_parameters 
you can include the following change in converge.yml [1] or rebase
on top of that patch.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/746595/28/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_derived_parameters/molecule/default/converge.yml'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-09-08 16:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

-1 for now as changes are needed. It's coming along nicely though. Please make the suggested changes and get the unit test and linters green in CI so I can re-review.

Overall I see the following break down of changes:

- 4 tasks files (derive-host*, derive-ovs-dpdk*, derive-sriov*, main)
- 2 filters (number_list, number_range) 
- 2 tests for the 2 new filters
- 4 modules (tripleo_get_dpdk_* + tripleo_get_host_cpus)
- 4 modules tests for the 4 new filters

This is good, I don't think overall files are missing, but we need to see a CI run get past the syntax and unit tests. I've added a few suggestions on next steps."}, {'account_id': 22865, 'date': '2020-09-09 08:23:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks John Fulton for your review comments.
could not run test cases due to glanceclient error and will update the ci test cases once fixed the issues.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-09-10 16:28:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> Thanks John Fulton for your review comments.

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-14 16:41:47.000000000', 'message': 'Fix compatibility issue in tripleo callback

The default callback sets some compatibility options but does not
properly do it in both the ways that are used. The show_per_host_start
is a compatibility option but the default callback uses get_option(...)
which checks for the existance in _plugin_options. Since it is not
defined there, the callback fails hard and the function no longer works.
This change adds our own compatibility layer to ensure the compatibility
options are set in _plugin_options until we can get a fix upstream.

Change-Id: I476aee9863ad63ce6d7ccf9350dae8540a37f017
Closes-Bug: #1895571
'}]
commit_message:
Fix compatibility issue in tripleo callback

The default callback sets some compatibility options but does not
properly do it in both the ways that are used. The show_per_host_start
is a compatibility option but the default callback uses get_option(...)
which checks for the existance in _plugin_options. Since it is not
defined there, the callback fails hard and the function no longer works.
This change adds our own compatibility layer to ensure the compatibility
options are set in _plugin_options until we can get a fix upstream.

Change-Id: I476aee9863ad63ce6d7ccf9350dae8540a37f017
Closes-Bug: #1895571

[{'created': '2020-09-03 21:49:41.000000000', 'message': 'The general usage of verify() is if you are doing something like:

 ports = row.ports
 ports.append('newport')
 row.ports = ports

where you read a value from the db, modify it, then overwrite it.
The setkey/addvalue/delvalue mutate functions make it largely
unnecessary to use verify(), so this patch removes those.

This cherry pick required a small change to address the following
pep8 error:
./neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/commands.py:717:48:
H703  Multiple positional placeholders
              "Can't update external IDs") % (self.table, self.record)
                                         ^

Change-Id: Idd42491dcaa10ec36c963b477438eaa2336ef3a0
(cherry picked from commit b11dd3836eba35d65561f582660fa081abd49c19)

commit_message:
Remove some unnecessary usages of verify()

The general usage of verify() is if you are doing something like:

 ports = row.ports
 ports.append('newport')
 row.ports = ports

where you read a value from the db, modify it, then overwrite it.
The setkey/addvalue/delvalue mutate functions make it largely
unnecessary to use verify(), so this patch removes those.

This cherry pick required a small change to address the following
pep8 error:
./neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/commands.py:717:48:
H703  Multiple positional placeholders
              "Can't update external IDs") % (self.table, self.record)
                                         ^

Change-Id: Idd42491dcaa10ec36c963b477438eaa2336ef3a0
(cherry picked from Neutron commit b11dd3836eba35d65561f582660fa081abd49c19)

Floating IP port forwarding by ml2/ovn uses OVN load balancers.
Integration tests with ovn_octavia_provider here are done to
ensure that these two functionalities can coexist.

commit_message:
Add integration tests with port forwarding

Floating IP port forwarding by ml2/ovn uses OVN load balancers.
Integration tests with ovn_octavia_provider here are done to
ensure that these two functionalities can coexist.

Change-Id: Iac335aec00bdfe27cd079469d67c8d0f92ae25eb

stable/victoria branch creation

Proposing stable/victoria branch creation for all client and non-client
libraries that had not requested it at freeze time.

Change-Id: Idd638b5e5859a4af9651a405d93600c0ccda2a36

commit_message:
Stop using shaman

Shaman packages are not stable and generates
breakages in our gates quite frequently.

Use packages available in download.ceph.com instead.

Change-Id: I0eab8ad25112511b0c4dd4b7796b4cda821bca8b

commit_message:
Change mariadb image to mariadb-server

Since change [1] merged we have two mariadb images (mariadb and mariadb-server)
Let's use mariadb-server in kolla-ansible, so we can deprecate mariadb image.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/710217/

Change-Id: I4ae2ccaaba8fb516f469f4ce8628e8c61de03f0d

commit_message:
Add dependency repo files and commands to repo_setup

This review adds the first dependency repo file and
dep_repo_* to include dependency repos in repo
setup. This allows tripleo ci testing of dependency
repos under development.

The first dependency jobs - for centos 8 stream -
are added in https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/29219/.

Change-Id: Ica3af2d69e5e1552c6e56e3be45b2af0d83b7f24

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: Ib2653b7490922c10763321572390fca3aaeafa33
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

doh, I only rebased that'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-09-10 10:44:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Could you update the job to make job-output.txt more useful? I'm looking at https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/6dfc30db2e864f179df0b35af52c6b1c/log/job-output.txt and it gives me no clue what happened or where to look. After some time I managed to find the failed log, but I'm worried that most contributors will just ignore the job instead. Maybe `tail -n100` the failed log?

Doing this will be a pre-requisite for ever making this job voting. LGTM for now."}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-09-10 10:48:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Could you update the job to make job-output.txt more useful? I'm
 > looking at https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/6dfc30db2e864f179df0b35af52c6b1c/log/job-output.txt
 > and it gives me no clue what happened or where to look. After some
 > time I managed to find the failed log, but I'm worried that most
 > contributors will just ignore the job instead. Maybe `tail -n100`
 > the failed log?
 > 
 > Doing this will be a pre-requisite for ever making this job voting.
 > LGTM for now.

job-output.txt is usually bad for debugging and one should look in job-output.json instead. That said, Zuul already formats the failure in the main view: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/6dfc30db2e864f179df0b35af52c6b1c/
is not that what you are really looking for?"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-09-10 10:50:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Ah, great, did not notice that. I guess we should just un-teach people to look at job-output.txt :)'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-09-14 11:04:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-09-17 14:56:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

recheck

just merged'}]

commit_message:
[CI] Check with Kolla Ansible

Introduce a (currently) non-voting job that tests Bifrost
with Kolla-Ansible (dependency of Kayobe too).
This tests both whether Bifrost image is buildable
and deployable.

This is to detect issues like [1] early.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/750146

Change-Id: I4f308922e6219b35e38afb547350ca95e0dfbc2a
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/750314

commit_message:
Recover support for installing stable/ussuri

While not encouraged, it's sometimes requested. This change checks
git_branch and avoids http_basic with JSON RPC.

Story: #2008151
Task: #40896
Change-Id: I38b55e060fe363e2e6f569f10b6d6aab6cb8d12c

commit_message:
Support building source images with in-review changes

Following this change it is possible to add 'Depends-On' lines to a
kolla-ansible commit message that point to reviews in other projects.
For example, this could be used to test building and deploying container
images containing a change to the nova project that is currently in
review.

Change-Id: I7630b7b56670eb6b7e628e5f6e95cc25f8c85a08
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/607159

This patch updates the tempest plugin regex for the grenade job
to run the tests tagged with the "smoke" attribute.

[CI] Support building source images with in-review changes

The Kolla-Ansible part.

This switches Kolla-Ansible to use the kolla-build-config role
instead of generating config locally.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/607159
Change-Id: I859acbe4f84ccbdc53764574a58e6f0fab4094a3

commit_message:
[CI] Support building source images with in-review changes

Following this change it is possible to add 'Depends-On' lines to a
kolla commit message that point to reviews in other projects. For
example, this could be used to test building and deploying container
images containing a change to the nova project that is currently in
review.

It also allows to introduce jobs testing against Kolla in other
projects.

The kolla-build-config Ansible role can also be used by other projects,
such as kolla-ansible, to generate the necessary configuration.

This takes us closer to the Kolla Builder - Next Generation concept [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014255.html

Change-Id: Ia2efa6b5d7278b75ab8dec23207f92d6bd7c58f0
Co-Authored-By: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Temporarily disable ceilometer (currently broken)""

Ceilometer integration is broken again:

gnocchi.cli.manage: Upgrading indexer SQLAlchemyIndexer: mysql+pymysql://***:***@127.0.0.1/gnocchi?charset=utf8
[...]
pymysql.err.OperationalError: (3822, "Duplicate check constraint name 'ck_started_before_ended'.")

This reverts commit afa2701268c4686245023d13df08edf293805bed.

Change-Id: I3472faf2f3c2a1ab8f921bcb8a802e1461911f2d

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-14 10:08:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix kolla_set_configs --check with a directory

There are several issues with kolla_set_configs --check:

1. We calculate the destination path incorrectly when comparing a file
   in a directory, due to passing arguments to os.path.relpath in the
   wrong order
2. For directories that have not changed, we also attempt to compare
   them as files, which fails when they are open()ed.
3. If the config JSON does not have a config_files key, it fails with a
   KeyError.

The first two issues affect the fluentd container, which specifies
directories as the source, without using a glob. The third affects OVN
containers.

This patch fixes these issues.

Closes-Bug: #1890567

Change-Id: I8921befe51da4282121443849177a7ca5ebe8822
(cherry picked from commit c5320eb22386c34d83435fa0b9aa03b178996b52)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix kolla_set_configs --check with a directory

There are several issues with kolla_set_configs --check:

1. We calculate the destination path incorrectly when comparing a file
   in a directory, due to passing arguments to os.path.relpath in the
   wrong order
2. For directories that have not changed, we also attempt to compare
   them as files, which fails when they are open()ed.
3. If the config JSON does not have a config_files key, it fails with a
   KeyError.

The first two issues affect the fluentd container, which specifies
directories as the source, without using a glob. The third affects OVN
containers.

This patch fixes these issues.

Closes-Bug: #1890567

Change-Id: I8921befe51da4282121443849177a7ca5ebe8822
(cherry picked from commit c5320eb22386c34d83435fa0b9aa03b178996b52)

When validating storage group RDF states remove
SyncInProg state. Fixes issue on slower systems where
SyncInProg state was still present from previous

rdf state consistency with Async and Metro modes.

Change-Id: Ic3f2b48c97840d052dca567089024dcbf51420c6
'}]
commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Allow SyncInProg with other states

When validating storage group RDF states remove
SyncInProg state. Fixes issue on slower systems where
SyncInProg state was still present from previous
volume creates causing failure when checking for
rdf state consistency with Async and Metro modes.

Change-Id: Ic3f2b48c97840d052dca567089024dcbf51420c6

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2020-04-08 23:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Can you explain the purpose of this? What does this buy us? There is already the local-cert-manager which is designed for use in testing, and will actually function... Is this just to avoid touching the filesystem (even /tmp/)?'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2020-04-09 07:55:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We want to add TLS test coverage in Tempest API. With the local certificate manager, there are no certificates pre-stored and there is no REST API that Tempest could use to upload certificates and have container refs returned to be used to e.g. create TLS-terminated listeners. The noop certificate manager includes certificates (cert, CA, CRL) already stored and with an "unlimited" range of available container refs ("cert-*", "ca-*", "crl-*").'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2020-04-13 09:47:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok... The idea for the local cert manager was that tempest could easily drop files into place and use whatever certs it wants, without having to rely on Octavia to include pre-generated ones. Does that workflow not solve for whatever you're trying to do?"}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2020-06-08 06:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2020-08-06 17:19:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2020-08-06 20:42:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Performance: replace unconditional include_tasks with import_tasks

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. For unconditionally included tasks, switching to
import_tasks provides a clear benefit.

Benchmarking of include vs. import is available at [1].

This change switches from include_tasks to import_tasks where there is
no condition applied to the include.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md#task-include-and-import

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ia45af4a198e422773d9f009c7f7b2e32ce9e3b97
(cherry picked from commit b685ac44e06722680cea840b6922977071f8bf7c)

This is bizarre. The error in the hacking test is only present with Python 3.8, and not present with 3.7.

It refers to the this particular line https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/src/commit/c36d015d4162d0e7ccd54063317895b663a1f45c/keystone/tests/unit/ksfixtures/hacking.py#L40

The offset should always have been 28 rather than 29 since it refers to the second list in the function definition. 45 (opening parenthesis) - 17 (line start offset) = 28. 29 would refer to x instead of the opening parenthesis.

I don't know why it was working fine with 29 until now."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-09-10 01:05:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
[goal] Migrate testing to ubuntu focal

As per victoria cycle testing runtime and community goal[1]
we need to migrate upstream CI/CD to Ubuntu Focal(20.04).

Fixing:
- bug#1886298
Bump the lower constraints for required deps which added python3.8 support
in their later version.

Story: #2007865
Task: #40190

Closes-Bug: #1886298

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/victoria/migrate-ci-cd-jobs-to-ubuntu-focal

Change-Id: I5712f29beee2bd7d8ba857c0ce2cd2287646d6b0

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > Formatting problem in the release note.  Also, question inline.

You are correct about the test for qos_policy_group_is_adaptive evaluating to True for any string value that is present in this extra-spec.  My idea was that this extra spec would simply not be in use at all for anything other than being set to "True", but we can easily do this test as 'if qos_policy_group_is_adaptive == "True":' if you think that is better?  Let me know and I can make that change.  Thanks for the review!'}, {'account_id': 32060, 'date': '2020-09-09 15:23:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 32060, 'date': '2020-09-09 15:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 26537, 'date': '2020-09-09 16:13:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

AFAIK the extra-spec will remain as the original string value "<is> True", so you'd need to compare == "<is> True".

You might use volume_utils.is_boolean_str to extract the actual bool value [0], as with other boolean values.

BTW, although the function is named "is_boolean_str", it returns False if the string is a boolean string "<is> False".

[{'created': '2020-07-15 21:49:33.000000000', 'message': '[NetApp] Adding support for Adaptive QoS in NetApp driver.

Added support for Adaptive QoS policies that have been pre-created on
the storage system, with the NetApp driver and clustered ONTAP version
9.4 or higher.  To use this feature, configure a Cinder volume type with
the following extra-specs:

netapp:qos_policy_group=<name_of_precreated_aqos_policy>
netapp:qos_policy_group_is_adaptive=True

Note that a cluster scoped account must be used in the driver
configuration in order to use QoS in clustered ONTAP.

Change-Id: Idcdbd042bb10f7381048fe4cb9fb870c3eebb6ce

commit_message:
[NetApp] Adding support for Adaptive QoS in NetApp driver.

Added support for Adaptive QoS policies that have been pre-created on
the storage system, with the NetApp driver and clustered ONTAP version
9.4 or higher.  To use this feature, configure a Cinder volume type with
the following extra-specs::

    netapp:qos_policy_group=<name_of_precreated_aqos_policy>
    netapp:qos_policy_group_is_adaptive="<is> True"

Note that a cluster scoped account must be used in the driver
configuration in order to use QoS in clustered ONTAP.

Partially-implements: bp netapp-adaptive-qos-support

Co-Authored-By: Lucio Seki <lucioseki@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Idcdbd042bb10f7381048fe4cb9fb870c3eebb6ce

[{'created': '2020-08-17 15:09:41.000000000', 'message': 'PowerMax Driver - Prevent unmanage with snapvx

Current unmanage operations attempt to clean up
any temporary snapshot links that exist on the volume.
However these links are not cleaned unless they have
reached their expiration timeout. Adding additional check
to prevent unmanage from completing unless all temporary
links have been cleared.

Change-Id: I3409308eb0b37352b069ec250db6adb9e082a27d
'}]
commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Prevent unmanage with snapvx

Current unmanage operations attempt to clean up
any temporary snapshot links that exist on the volume.
However these links are not cleaned unless they have
reached their expiration timeout. Adding additional check
to prevent unmanage from completing unless all temporary
links have been cleared.

Change-Id: I3409308eb0b37352b069ec250db6adb9e082a27d

 user leaks the host fqdn in fault msg of instance.Removing the
'host' field from the error message of HypervisorUnavaiable
cause it's leaking host fqdn to non-admin users. The admin user will
see the Hypervisor unavailable exception msg but will be able to figure

commit_message:
Removed the host FQDN from the exception message

Deletion of an instance after disabling the hypervisor by a non-admin
 user leaks the host fqdn in fault msg of instance.Removing the
'host' field from the error message of HypervisorUnavaiable
cause it's leaking host fqdn to non-admin users. The admin user will
see the Hypervisor unavailable exception msg but will be able to figure
on which compute host the guest is on and that the connection is broken.

Change-Id: I0eae19399670f59c17c9a1a24e1bfcbf1b514e7b
Closes-Bug: #1851587
(cherry picked from commit a89ffab83261060bbb9dedb2b8de6297b2d07efd)
(cherry picked from commit ff82601204e9d724b3032dc94c49fa5c8de2699b)

commit_message:
Stop testing ceilometer and aodh

Ceilometer uses gnocchi as the default backend. Also we use
gnocchi based aodh alarms in tests.

gnocchi seems unmaintained with last commit a year or so ago and
does not look like the openstack telemetry team is involved in
that project.

It's better to disable the services and tests in heat to avoid
broken gate like last time, where we fixed it by banning latest
pecan release[1] that does not work with python-gnocchiclient.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/746261/

Change-Id: Id2ffdf6b9d342e800bab4a94ec46742228361ee8

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-15 08:57:27.000000000', 'message': 'Performance: remove one include_tasks in nova-cell

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. The nova-cell role uses include_tasks twice when generating
certificates and keys for libvirt TLS. While a dynamic include makes
sense here for a non-default feature, we can use one include rather than
two with the same effect. Since this task runs against compute nodes the
overhead is significant.

See [1] for benchmarks of include_tasks and import_tasks.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ic687d2f7d4625aede386e576ebb174da72142756
(cherry picked from commit 3c02c966cb8b07462538bbdba0b7deed4cb40a90)
'}]
commit_message:
Performance: remove one include_tasks in nova-cell

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. The nova-cell role uses include_tasks twice when generating
certificates and keys for libvirt TLS. While a dynamic include makes
sense here for a non-default feature, we can use one include rather than
two with the same effect. Since this task runs against compute nodes the
overhead is significant.

See [1] for benchmarks of include_tasks and import_tasks.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ic687d2f7d4625aede386e576ebb174da72142756
(cherry picked from commit 3c02c966cb8b07462538bbdba0b7deed4cb40a90)

commit_message:
Enable py3 on dib release 7

Enable python3 on buildimage for centos7 and drop py2 support.

With https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741868 merged on dib, py3 is
pre-installed on chroot base image so now we can build image
on older branches w/ py2 elements and on newer branches with
py3 elements with the same dib code (no more pinning).

Change-Id: Ic26084752943dc99edd32d8d8c8abf5560433aeb

subject: Don't unset Instance.old_flavor, new_flavor until necessary

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-11 16:32:08.000000000', 'message': "Don't unset Instance.old_flavor, new_flavor until necessary

Since change Ia6d8a7909081b0b856bd7e290e234af7e42a2b38, the resource
tracker's 'drop_move_claim' method has been capable of freeing up
resource usage. However, this relies on accurate resource reporting.
It transpires that there's a race whereby the resource tracker's
'update_available_resource' periodic task can end up not accounting for
usage from migrations that are in the process of being completed. The
root cause is the resource tracker's reliance on the stashed flavor in a
given migration record [1]. Previously, this information was deleted by
the compute manager at the start of the confirm migration operation [2].
The compute manager would then call the virt driver [3], which could
take a not insignificant amount of time to return, before finally
dropping the move claim. If the periodic task ran between the clearing
of the stashed flavor and the return of the virt driver, it would find a
migration record with no stashed flavor and would therefore ignore this
record for accounting purposes [4], resulting in an incorrect record for
the compute node, and an exception when the 'drop_move_claim' attempts
to free up the resources that aren't being tracked.

The solution to this issue is pretty simple. Instead of unsetting the
old flavor record from the migration at the start of the various move
operations, do it afterwards.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1288
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/manager.py#L4310-L4315
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/manager.py#L4330-L4331
[4] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1300

Change-Id: I4760b01b695c94fa371b72216d398388cf981d28
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1879878
Related-Bug: #1834349
Related-Bug: #1818914
(cherry picked from commit 44376d2e212e0f9405a58dc7fc4d5b38d70ac42e)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't unset Instance.old_flavor, new_flavor until necessary

Since change Ia6d8a7909081b0b856bd7e290e234af7e42a2b38, the resource
tracker's 'drop_move_claim' method has been capable of freeing up
resource usage. However, this relies on accurate resource reporting.
It transpires that there's a race whereby the resource tracker's
'update_available_resource' periodic task can end up not accounting for
usage from migrations that are in the process of being completed. The
root cause is the resource tracker's reliance on the stashed flavor in a
given migration record [1]. Previously, this information was deleted by
the compute manager at the start of the confirm migration operation [2].
The compute manager would then call the virt driver [3], which could
take a not insignificant amount of time to return, before finally
dropping the move claim. If the periodic task ran between the clearing
of the stashed flavor and the return of the virt driver, it would find a
migration record with no stashed flavor and would therefore ignore this
record for accounting purposes [4], resulting in an incorrect record for
the compute node, and an exception when the 'drop_move_claim' attempts
to free up the resources that aren't being tracked.

The solution to this issue is pretty simple. Instead of unsetting the
old flavor record from the migration at the start of the various move
operations, do it afterwards.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1288
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/manager.py#L4310-L4315
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/manager.py#L4330-L4331
[4] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6557d67/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1300

Change-Id: I4760b01b695c94fa371b72216d398388cf981d28
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1879878
Related-Bug: #1834349
Related-Bug: #1818914
(cherry picked from commit 44376d2e212e0f9405a58dc7fc4d5b38d70ac42e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-15 08:58:46.000000000', 'message': 'Performance: remove one include_tasks in nova-cell

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. The nova-cell role uses include_tasks twice when generating
certificates and keys for libvirt TLS. While a dynamic include makes
sense here for a non-default feature, we can use one include rather than
two with the same effect. Since this task runs against compute nodes the
overhead is significant.

See [1] for benchmarks of include_tasks and import_tasks.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ic687d2f7d4625aede386e576ebb174da72142756
(cherry picked from commit 3c02c966cb8b07462538bbdba0b7deed4cb40a90)
'}]
commit_message:
Performance: remove one include_tasks in nova-cell

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. The nova-cell role uses include_tasks twice when generating
certificates and keys for libvirt TLS. While a dynamic include makes
sense here for a non-default feature, we can use one include rather than
two with the same effect. Since this task runs against compute nodes the
overhead is significant.

See [1] for benchmarks of include_tasks and import_tasks.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ic687d2f7d4625aede386e576ebb174da72142756
(cherry picked from commit 3c02c966cb8b07462538bbdba0b7deed4cb40a90)

commit_message:
Move process-stackviz role from Tempest to Devstack

process-stackviz role currently defined in Tempest and used
in tempest jobs. Issue with having it in branchless Tempest is that any
fix in that role cannot be backported to older Tempest. Also stackviz is
not Tempest things it is only used by Tempest jobs.

Stackviz can be considered as a service similar to Tempest so inatlling it in
Devstack side make sense. Also that will give us advantage to handle the
branch specific fixes or backpoting the fixes.

This can solve the current issues we are facing on rocky branch
- https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/c1e2da80537448bfb24331fb4198a931/console#4/0/29/controller

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737037/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737075/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737076/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737077/
Change-Id: Ide74cdf7967975fba9a3230007b35798d23e8bd2

commit_message:
Adding description for testcases - compute part11

When Tempest is used in customer site, often we are required to
provide a testcase list including testcase names and descriptions.
Now no this kind of doc is available, so we can add descriptions
with the format of doc string for every testcase, so later we
can generata such a testcase description list.

There are hundreds of testcases missing descriptions, so we can
add them gradually, and limit the modified files in one patch
for the convenience of reviewing.

Change-Id: I5bf95ca579b731ca4baefb590edb8e265126ce4f
partially-implements: blueprint testcase-description

commit_message:
tests: Remove '_FakeImageService'

Migrate unit tests over to the new GlanceFixture, allowing us to fully
delete '_FakeImageService' and various helpers.

Change-Id: I3e3d9bbd32aa2fe0777681f21ba827610d5b3040
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Improve pip install process for offline deployment.

    * "Use distribution-provided pip"
    * "Use python's pip module invocation method"
    * "Install pip earlier in order to avoid multiple installation"
    * "Remove pip_version variable requirement and call"

    Change-Id: Id0e738044a1931f9d611a7281a48ea4a593f1cf1
    Closes-bug: #1893204

Change-Id: Ibaa2d9e51266086862cfb48f55e37f1e642ad378

Remove translation sections from setup.cfg

These translation sections are not needed anymore,
Babel can generate translation files without them.

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. For unconditionally included tasks, switching to
import_tasks provides a clear benefit.

Benchmarking of include vs. import is available at [1].

This change switches from include_tasks to import_tasks where there is

commit_message:
Performance: replace unconditional include_tasks with import_tasks

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. For unconditionally included tasks, switching to
import_tasks provides a clear benefit.

Benchmarking of include vs. import is available at [1].

This change switches from include_tasks to import_tasks where there is
no condition applied to the include.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md#task-include-and-import

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ia45af4a198e422773d9f009c7f7b2e32ce9e3b97
(cherry picked from commit b685ac44e06722680cea840b6922977071f8bf7c)

commit_message:
Need to have stable implementation of api

_get_router() api has different implemenation
in tempest plugins as compared to scenario-
manager.
Hence, In order to achieve stability among the
plugins and scenario manager, modification is
required

Implements: blueprint tempest-scenario-manager-stable
Signed-off by: Soniya Vyas<svyas@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I1dcf77da7d71dda728bf844baabdfa2e6a3f446a

commit_message:
Revert "Make mock import python 2.7 compatible"

We don't support py2.7 anymore, so this code is not needed.

We've also removed mock from test-requirements, so it would
not be present anyway.

This reverts commit 0f883090916cf84309dddb1cdf6dd51265e36a0a.

Change-Id: I06a541523f7da1bea7db5b5d16e4ce36a5031bb9

commit_message:
Consume ceph, prom, grafana containers from quay.io

In order to reduce dependency from docker.io. it switched to
the registry url of following containers to quay.io:
ceph - quay.ceph.io/ceph-ci
alertmanager, prometheus and node-exporter - quay.io/prometheus
grafana - quay.io/app-sre

It also updates the ceph daemon image tag from
v4.0.12-stable-4.0-nautilus-centos-7-x86_64
to v4.0.13-stable-4.0-nautilus-centos-7-x86_64.

Change-Id: I8be781e49765cd800f8a10b028ab1574292fdc67
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e6836c5979344ad42176fb09bb5d9b9aad6e5754)

Let's enable undercloud nova for fs020.

commit_message:
Allow to pass a static inventory to the validator CLI

This is especially interesting when doing a full upgrade, as you might
end in a situation where you don't have any running services on the
undercloud.

This patch will be needed down to stable/train.

Change-Id: Ife48ed6ec5e5ae7c9ff1695c83e1d3312dc1205a
(cherry picked from commit 4c713b189cab4091fec6a53edb3b45a9737546c1)

commit_message:
Do not check created_at attribute in test_service_list test

Tempest could be used not only after initial deployment but for
cloud verification during operations or after update. We don't
need to check that services are created today.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/751657/
Change-Id: Ifc3cb1933a591ce1fe05fe11d5e07b78a0e61375

commit_message:
Performance: use a single config file for fluentd

Currently we generate multiple fluentd configuration files for inputs,
filters, formatters and outputs.
These are then included from the main td-agent.conf configuration file.
With a large number of hosts, this can take a long time to template.

Benchmarking of templating is available at [1].

This change switches to a single fluentd configuration file, with the
include done locally. For the default template files included with Kolla
Ansible we use Jinja includes, but this does not work with templates in
a different directory. We therefore use the Ansible template lookup
plugin, which has a slightly higher overhead than a jinja include, but
far lower than generating multiple templates. This should drastically
improve the performance of this task.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/template.md

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ia8623be0aa861fea3e54d2c9e1c971dfd8e3afa9

commit_message:
Performance: use a single config file for logrotate

Currently we generate a logrotate configuration file for each enabled
service. These are then included from a logrotate.d directory. With a
large number of hosts, this can take a long time to template.

Benchmarking of templating is available at [1].

This change switches to a single logrotate configuration file for all
services, with the include done locally using jinja. This should
drastically improve the performance of this task.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/template.md

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I39cfa70bef6560f615cad516c43aaef6a523b964

commit_message:
Log beginning of request processing to INFO

This patch adds an INFO log statement to log when a request begins
processing.  This should help in measuring how long request are taking
to be processed.

Change-Id: I2fa29cb07a652d58d78c6d721cdbb756033d7fea

commit_message:
Add neutron-ovs inclusion before other user environments

neutron-ovs.yaml environment file has default parameters
required for ml2-ovs plugin, but some of the parameters
will be overriden by other environment files
(like neutron-sriov.yaml) or user specific includes.
Include neutron-ovs.yaml file before all user inclusions.

Change-Id: I09b9d0b50b969ee66cbad914dc29db2367b8426c
(cherry picked from commit dd184988862e6d10b127658bcebc4662f232f1cd)

If a custom CA file is configured via [api] cafile, currently

commit_message:
Use keystoneauth1 config option loading for masakari client

If a custom CA file is configured via [api] cafile, currently
communication with Keystone will fail, since the session is not created
using this CA file. The [api] insecure option is also ignored.

This change fixes the issue by using keystoneauth loading for the auth
and session, to ensure all standard configuration options are supported.

Change-Id: Idd58b72f7f5242e8135fec71b42adf5dd1852417
Closes-Bug: #1873736

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-14 10:16:46.000000000', 'message': 'Performance: replace unconditional include_tasks with import_tasks

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. For unconditionally included tasks, switching to
import_tasks provides a clear benefit.

Benchmarking of include vs. import is available at [1].

This change switches from include_tasks to import_tasks where there is
no condition applied to the include.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md#task-include-and-import

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ia45af4a198e422773d9f009c7f7b2e32ce9e3b97
(cherry picked from commit b685ac44e06722680cea840b6922977071f8bf7c)
'}]
commit_message:
Performance: replace unconditional include_tasks with import_tasks

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. For unconditionally included tasks, switching to
import_tasks provides a clear benefit.

Benchmarking of include vs. import is available at [1].

This change switches from include_tasks to import_tasks where there is
no condition applied to the include.

[1] https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-scaling/blob/master/doc/include-and-import.md#task-include-and-import

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: Ia45af4a198e422773d9f009c7f7b2e32ce9e3b97
(cherry picked from commit b685ac44e06722680cea840b6922977071f8bf7c)

commit_message:
Add checks for volume status when rebuilding

When rebuilding, we should only allow detaching
the volume with 'in-use' status, volume in status
such as 'retyping' should not allowed.

Change-Id: I7f93cfd18f948134c9cb429dea55740d2cf97994
Closes-Bug: #1489304
(cherry picked from commit 10e9a9b9fc62a3cf72c3717e3621ed95d3cf5519)
(cherry picked from commit bcbeae2c605f4ab4ad805dddccac802928a180b6)
(cherry picked from commit 683005df39cbb825ff0702cd91773ad16d7b3998)

commit_message:
Update shebang for Python 3 script

The feature-flags.py script uses pathlib which is only supported in
Python 3. Update shebang to ensure it is run with the correct
interpreter.

Change-Id: I69ea0c90f68909399709626bddfc418e9df31acc
(cherry picked from commit 7d4d48b1c4eca2e0292e6eaa4bcc00969a068139)
